ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: office hours and occasionally computing lab at the beginning of the semester
Virital lecture combined with a synchronous friday courses(some weeks)
Live virtual lectures and workshops over zoom.
Slack, one on one Zoom meetings with the professor, coding assignments
I also watched recorded lectures whenever I wasn't able to make it to the live lectures.
occasional pre-recorded lectures
Lectures were recorded and avaliable on Canvas. Additionally, Prof. Geha scheduled one-on-one meetings throughout the semester, and utilized Slack to share resources with students.
Sometimes there were recorded lectures.
virtual lectures, all of which were recorded (and we were given the option of watching them instead of going to the live zoom calls if needed)
Friday classes were more like a virtual seminar; there was a lot of class participation.

Lecture was meant to be a live virtual lecture on Mondays and Wednesday, with more discussion based seminars happening on Friday. However, it was clear that the course was better suited online as a live virtual lecture, and the class geared toward that direction of live virtual lectures every class period near the end of the course.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: observational astronomy, telescopes, python, data analysis, science writing
I developed valuable and practical skills to perform research and further my understanding of astrophysics.
I learned programming

I learned a lot about the fundamentals of astrophysics research, from important theory concepts and their applications to technical aspects such as equipment, data analysis methods, coding (in python) and scientific communication through writing.
I learned a lot about astronomy, astronomy imaging techniques, Python coding to clean and analyze data, writing telescope proposals.
I learned about data reduction in astronomy using python.
skills for astronomy research, programming with python, and general knowledge about astronomical methods

I learned concepts pertaining to the basics of observational astronomy, telescopes, and data reduction (using data science tools in Python). The course provided good hands-on experience with Jupyter notebooks, Numpy, and Matplotlib. Additionally, I learned how to improve my science writing skills as part of the telescope allocation committee final project (i.e. mock telescope proposal).

Learned the different techniques used in astronomy research, such as telescope optics, observing, CCD cameras, spectra, data reduction, and some radio astronomy. Also learned how to use python on astronomical data, such as images and spectra.

Prof. Geha said the goal of this course is to "make us useful to her" (and other astro researchers), and I think she did that! We got a great intro to python, optical astronomy, data reduction, and how to turn observation data over multiple filters into pretty images. I had no idea there was so much work to be done after observation data is taken.
Research skills relevant to astronomy

I learned important information about the basics of research in astronomy, as well as how the telescope proposal process works and how to write well in this context. Science communication was the most valuable skill I learned!

I learned a lot about the astrophysics research process, including how telescopes are designed, how observations were made, and how to extract data from raw Science Image files. I learned lots of new programming techniques and tools using Jupyter Notebook. I also learned how to write a research proposal and how telescope time is allocated in the astrophysics research world.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Marla is a great prof and she curated a great line up of lectures for this course. Everything was solid, although easing up on the psets would be great for the future -- it certainly felt like a marathon at times. the TAC meeting at the end of the year is also nice, but we were all so tired by that point that I don't know if we all got too much out of it.
It is very strong in its practicality, and its usefullness.
I think there could be more emphasis on python in the lectures. Though teaching myself these skills was valuable, I was often lost at times.
I would have liked a little more emphasis on programming rather than astro.

Professor Geha is an absolute delight to work with. She is very personable, and generous with her time and feedback. As for the course itself, it was well-structured with weekly coding problem sets that were good methods of practicing what was learned in lecture. The final project was especially useful, and I have a much more nuanced understanding of what makes for good science writing.

Strengths: The course was really good at teaching (which is special, and unique amongst courses in general!).  In every lecture and every assignment, the prof made herself super variable for questions of any kind, which was really helpful. This was an astro class where I really learned things.

Weaknesses: Mmmmm maybe that a lot of the stuff we learned in class wasn't necessarily relevant to the telescope proposal? But that's barely a comment, this was a great class
Strengths: straightforward, interesting, and relevant content for astro majors.
the course was also organized well. no major weaknesses

Strengths: Exposes students to data science tools in Python (valuable to not only astronomy, but also other fields), good overall pacing, good class size, unique final project that teaches science writing skills.
Weaknesses: Very few. Grading for a few assignments was a bit slow, though this was an unusual semester for all involved. A bit more initial guidance on the requirements for the final TAC project might have also been helpful, though most questions were eventually resolved in one-on-one meetings and over Slack.

The class is jammed packed with information most astrophysics and astronomy majors should know. Both the basics and a lot of the advanced ideas are discussed and you learn a lot from doing the problem sets. Sometimes, I felt the problem sets had ideas that were not discussed fully in class, but going to office hours and getting help from the Professor and TA was extremely helpful.

Strengths: great overview of optical astronomy and introduction to data processing in python. Weaknesses: didn't really cover error/uncertainties as much as we should have, but this was due to the online format and zoom-exhaustion. Would also have been nice to learn better practices, functions, and more flow control in python to improve our code.
This is a very good course
Its main strength is the enthusiasm and helpful environment created by Prof. Geha. I also really enjoyed how the course gives hands-on experience in python and in scientific writing.

I thought this class was well suited as a virtual lecture, and Prof. Geha did a great job explaining how to break down science research data both theoretically and practically. However, I sometimes felt that the slides and materials in the course were a little vague, which was especially apparent when working on the problem sets. Some fundamental, objective information taught in the class became very vague and confusing when reviewing the slides. Finally, I really thought that the research proposal was a very cool final project to work on, as it gave us valuable insight on the research process that no one really seems to talk about.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: She was understanding on a lot of psets and extended the deadline which was prime.

I think the synchronous seminars monday and wednesday worked quite well, and a synchronous on Friday was a great solution! I think there was good participation from the students  thanks to an open work environment.

The best part of this course over Zoom was the availability (and choice) of engagement. Prof Geha met with us one on one, which was super helpful in getting know her, feeling engaged in the class, and actually feeling like I could understand what was going on. Slack was a great tool to stay updated on deadlines and communicate easily with other students in the class. Lectures were synchronous, which was good because that forced staying on track, but if you were having a bad day or something you could keep your camera off and not have to be totally on top of things, which was also good. I think this was a perfect example of physics teaching during a pandemic.
Recording lectures is a must, which this course did. Additionally, having a slack channel for ease of communication helped keep me engaged in the class, so that was a great idea.
i think it went quite smoothly. if need be the lectures could have definitely been pre-recorded rather than live

The instructors adapted well to the pandemic situation. They used Slack to communicate with students (extremely helpful) and were responsive to questions. Additionally, the professor was understanding if extensions were needed (transparent extension policy in the syllabus, quick to respond to extension requests, and gave clear announcements to the class if the deadline was changed for all students).

The class had a live lecture, but also had the lectures recorded so students were able to watch later if they could not attend class or were in a different time zone. The class did have a participation grade based on a spreadsheet where you could ask questions you had about that day's lecture.
I felt as if the professor was always easily and willingly accessible which was very helpful. Also on Fridays we would have a more hands-on type class to keep up engaged.

This was one of the best adapted classes I took this semester. Python and power points were frequently screen shared, so it was pretty easy to adapt anyway. I loved the use of slack, it made asking quick and simple questions really easy (like if I saw Prof. Geha at office hours or ran into her), and made it so I didn't feel like I had to write a formal email for every little thing. Also allowed us to see other's questions and work through pset issues.

I think the class was really accomodating for the current environment, especially with getting help in office hours and creating a seminar-like environment where I felt comfortable participating digitally.

I really appreciated how the lectures were recorded, and how Prof. Geha also allowed students to ask questions both during recorded lecture and after she stopped recording, so that their questions would not be saved in the final recordings. It really encouraged us to ask questions. Near the beginning of the course, we needed to prepare questions before class or create some questions after watching the lecture, but I felt that the questions proposed were forced and not very helpful. Because these questions were tied to students names as a way of gauging participation, it was time consuming and often stressful to make sure good questions were asked. Deadlines were also flexible when times were busy, especially in the latter half of the class, which really helped with stress and scheduling.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, although the psets can be tedious at times, this is a great course for how astro research is done.
Absolutely, anyone interested in astro should take this course.

Yes! Though it was hard to pick up at first, the class was really rewarding, and I use the skills I learned very frequently out of the classroom. This class may be required for astro majors, but it is INSANELY helpful.
Yes. Good combination of Astro/Coding.

Absolutely! It a must for majors, but I recommend it to anyone wanting to pursue research in astronomy and astrophysics, or people who are simply interested in picking up some technical skills relating to this field.

Yes! This class is really geared towards supporting students and making sure they actually learn the material, not tricking us or making us confused. If you're an astro major, take this course to learn applicable coding skills (and life skills!). If you're a physics major, take this course to learn about astro. If you're another kind of major, take this course if you can get in!

This is a great course if you are an astro major and want to learn fundamental data manipulation and reduction techniques with Python, while also learning about how telescopes and other astronomical devices work at a more in-depth level. If you're not an astro major and find any of these things interesting, this is still a great course to take.
yes, i think it was very helpful in outlining the basics of astronomy research

Yes! The course teaches valuable programming skills that are applicable in many fields. Additionally, the TAC final project is a unique assignment that teaches students how to improve their science writing skills. Even if a student is not planning on majoring in astronomy or physics, I recommend this course. The non-astronomy/physics student may occasionally need to do a very small amount of extra reading on their own and/or ask classmates for help with astronomy concepts, but this does not detract from the course overall, as lectures are quite accessible.
Yes, the class is very useful for astronomy and astrophysics majors, but it also taught me a lot of new things about coding with python.

Yes I would because the professor was absolutely amazing and provided great feedback on work. Also, the class and topics covered were very interesting. I  went into this course knowing nothing about coding or python and now feel as if I have a very solid foundation and understanding of how to use it in astronomy.

Absolutely! I believe it is a required course for astro majors (and registration preference is given to sophomore and junior astro majors), but it's a lot of fun and you should try to take it anyway if there's space in the class and you're interested in learning cool (and employable) applications of python or are interested in the process behind making pretty space images :)
I would! I think it is a great course to learn whether you are into astronomy or not, and what parts of astronomy you may be interested in!

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student, mainly because I think the course materials are very interesting and Prof. Geha is a great instructor who provides great feedback and advice. This class is especially great for those who are planning to do physics or astrophysics research.
